snippet.title: Amber Yang (MAOD)—Teaching and Presenting Online While Fostering Meaning, Community, and Engagement
snippet.description:
Tune into this presentation recorded on September 26, 2020, as part of our Summer 2020 Lecture series: Sheltering Together in Health. Every week, we feature guest speakers from different health disciplines and professors of the Holistic Health Studies program.

Amber Yang (she/her) is the Restorative Justice and Wellness Coordinator for a Northern California School District, where she works to disrupt the school to prison pipeline through mentoring and advocating, facilitating harm and compassion circles, and community building circles. She also provides consulting for teachers to help them create classrooms that foster relationships, inclusion, meaning, and other trauma-informed practices while still honoring academic content. A growing digital artist, Amber enjoys finding innovative and creative ways to engage online while we shelter-in-place.  She is currently pursuing a Master's Degree at Sonoma State in Organizational Change and Development where she is helping lead the team to create a restorative justice program at Sonoma State.

To follow more of the work that the Holistic Health Studies program is doing, visit our website at www.sfsu.edu/~ihhs or follow us on Instagram at @sfsuholistichealth
